Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, my phone buzzing in my hand. My partner’s eyes were red, their voice trembling as they recounted the impossible choice their boss had given them. They needed me—needed my full attention, my comfort, my words to help them feel less alone in the storm. But as I reached out to hold their hand, my phone vibrated again. A message from my friend flashed on the screen, short and sharp: “Can we talk?” My stomach twisted. I’d just realized the offhand joke I made earlier had cut deeper than I’d ever intended. I knew I had to call, to explain, to fix what I’d broken before the silence grew into something worse. My partner’s hand squeezed mine, searching for reassurance, while my friend waited on the other end of the line, hurting because of me. I felt split in two, torn between being the anchor my partner needed and the honest friend I wanted to be. The weight of both expectations pressed down, and I sat frozen, phone in hand, heart pounding, unsure which need to answer first.
